column1: #Text=Starting materials for the preparation of the Sc12Co42Si30 polycrystalline samples were commercially available pure elements: scandium metal with a claimed purity of 99.99 ​at.%, Alfa-Aesar, Johnson Matthey, sublimed bulk pieces; polycrystalline silicon pieces, purity >99.99 ​at.%, H. C. Starck; cobalt pieces, purity 99.98 ​at.%, Fluka Chemicals.

#Text=Arc-melting of the elements in the desired ratio to give an overall sample weight of 2.00 ​g was performed on a water-cooled copper hearth under a puriﬁed argon atmosphere with Ti as the getter.
#Text=To ensure homogeneity, after the first melting, the solid ingot was turned over and re-melted twice.
#Text=Weight losses after arc melting were generally smaller than 0.5%.

#Text=For further heat treatment, the pellets were wrapped in tantalum foil, sealed in evacuated quartz tubes, annealed at T ​= ​800 ​°C for 350 ​h and subsequently quenched by submerging the tubes in cold water.
#Text=Single crystals of the new scandium cobalt silicide, having a metallic luster and being quite stable in air, were isolated by crushing the solidiﬁed samples.
#Text=Bulk and powdered samples were stable in the air for months.
